Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 327, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 907, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 907, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 764, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value is necessary, take the acceleration due to gravity to be \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 507, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 907, 660]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 608, 675]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 608, 704]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 704, 757, 720]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A bullet of mass \(0.2\mathrm{kg}\) is fired into a fixed vertical barrier. It enters the barrier horizontally with speed \(250\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) and emerges horizontally after a time \(T\) seconds with speed \(40\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\). There is a constant horizontal resisting force of magnitude \(1200\mathrm{N}\). Find \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The particle \(P\) is moving in a complete vertical circle about \(O\). The points \(A\) and \(B\) are on the circle, at opposite ends of a diameter, and such that \(OA\) makes an acute angle \(\alpha\) with the upward vertical through \(O\). The speed of \(P\) as it passes through \(A\) is \(\frac{3}{2}\sqrt{(ag)}\). The tension in the string when \(P\) is at \(B\) is four times the tension in the string when \(P\) is at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 170, 156, 188]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 170, 324, 188]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\cos \alpha = \frac{3}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Three uniform small spheres \(A, B\) and \(C\) have equal radii and masses \(3m, m\) and \(m\) respectively. The spheres are at rest in a straight line on a smooth horizontal surface, with \(B\) between \(A\) and \(C\). The coefficient of restitution between each pair of spheres is \(e\). Sphere \(A\) is projected directly towards \(B\) with speed \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 151, 917, 170]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(u\) and \(e\), expressions for the speeds of \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) after the first two collisions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 917, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The object is pivoted at \(A\) so that it can rotate freely about \(L\). The object is released from rest with the rod making an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the downward vertical. The greatest angular speed attained by the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 475, 134]]<|/det|>
object in the subsequent motion is \(\frac{9}{20}\sqrt{\left(\frac{g}{a}\right)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 147, 153, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 147, 316, 165]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 147, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 811, 92]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(W\), the reaction between the rod and the smooth rim of the bowl.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 544, 195, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 543, 324, 562]]<|/det|>
Find \(x\) in terms of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(T\) is the lifetime, in hours, of a randomly chosen battery of a particular type. It is given that \(T\) has a negative exponential distribution with mean 400 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 120, 154, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 554, 139]]<|/det|>
Write down the probability density function of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 297, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 297, 848, 316]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a battery of this type has a lifetime that is less than 500 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 540, 149, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 540, 443, 559]]<|/det|>
Find the median of the distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A pair of fair coins is thrown repeatedly until a pair of tails is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 398, 139]]<|/det|>
State the expected value of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 230, 154, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 230, 777, 249]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that exactly 3 throws are required to obtain a pair of tails.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 249]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 153, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 803, 426]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that fewer than 4 throws are required to obtain a pair of tails.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 584, 153, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 584, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Find the least integer \(N\) such that the probability of obtaining a pair of tails in fewer than \(N\) throws is more than 0.95.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 920, 123]]<|/det|> Two salesmen, \(A\) and \(B\), work at a company that arranges different types of holidays: self-catering, hotel and cruise. The table shows, for a random sample of 150 holidays, the number of each type arranged by each salesman. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 131, 798, 222]]<|/det|>
Type of holiday
Self-cateringHotelCruise
Salesman\(A\)253821
\(B\)282117
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 237, 920, 255]]<|/det|> Test at the \(10\%\) significance level whether the type of holiday arranged is independent of the salesman. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 253, 920, 271]]<|/det|> [8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A farmer grows large amounts of a certain crop. On average, the yield per plant has been \(0.75\mathrm{kg}\). The farmer has improved the soil in which the crop grows, and she claims that the yield per plant has increased. A random sample of 10 plants grown in the improved soil is chosen. The yields, \(x\mathrm{kg}\), are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 139, 603, 159]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 7.85\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 6.19\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 175, 153, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 175, 920, 209]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether the farmer's claim is justified, assuming a normal distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 192, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The means and variances for a random sample of 8 pairs of values of \(x\) and \(y\) taken from a bivariate distribution are given in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 116, 672, 185]]<|/det|>
MeanVariance
\(x\)3.31253.3086
\(y\)6.73757.9473

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 524, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 201, 123]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
A light spring has natural length \(a\) and modulus of elasticity \(k mg\). The spring lies on a smooth horizontal surface with one end attached to a fixed point \(O\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is attached to the other end of the spring. The system is in equilibrium with \(O P = a\). The particle is projected towards \(O\) with speed \(u\) and comes to instantaneous rest when \(O P = \frac{3}{4} a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 227, 153, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 222, 526, 245]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to show that \(k = \frac{16u^2}{ag}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 476, 186, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 476, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
Show that \(P\) performs simple harmonic motion and find the period of this motion, giving your answer in terms of \(u\) and \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 495, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(u\) and \(a\), the time that elapses before \(P\) first loses \(25\%\) of its initial kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 151, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
A company produces packets of sweets. Two different machines, \(A\) and \(B\), are used to fill the packets. The manager decides to assess the performance of the two machines. He selects a random sample of 50 packets filled by machine \(A\) and a random sample of 60 packets filled by machine \(B\). The masses of sweets, \(x \mathrm{kg}\), in packets filled by machine \(A\) and the masses of sweets, \(y \mathrm{kg}\), in packets filled by machine \(B\) are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 191, 727, 210]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 22.4\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 10.1\qquad \Sigma y = 28.8\qquad \Sigma y^2 = 16.3\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 217, 920, 266]]<|/det|>
A test at the \(\alpha \%\) significance level provides evidence that the mean mass of sweets in packets filled by machine \(A\) is less than the mean mass of sweets in packets filled by machine \(B\). Find the set of possible values of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 252, 920, 268]]<|/det|>
<mark>[12]
